title: What do Riot base their nerfs and buffs on?
body:
Just reading through patch notes, and they almost seem random as to which flavor of the month champ gets changed.

It's not the ban rates that dictate a change, cause I mean.. why would they trust the people playing their game to tell us what is unhealthy?

It's not the win rates, cause why would use success statistics to judge a champions strength?


What do they use?

replies.body: Feels like to me they nerf and buff champions based on the amount of people crying about them.
If that was the case, Yasuo would be Urgot tier.

They use a multitude of things.
Win rates
Ban rates
Pick rates
Viability of the champion ("strategic diversity")
Pro scene success
and of course, personal preferences

But Alistar loses more than he wins, is banned 4% of the time and picked 17% of the time.

So if they use win rates, ban rates or pick rates, why not pick on someone a little more suited?

Why not nerf something like Malphite, who has a 65% ban rate, 52% win rate and 9% pick rate?

65% ban rate, that's Shaco/Kassadin level shit, and look at them now, why doesn't malphite or Udyr ever get this treatment?

Remember that it depends on play in ALL ranks. Ali may have an overall win rate of less than 50%, and may not get picked or banned much, but he is decently popular in the higher ranks because he is actually very strong.

Malphite likely will be hit with a nerf as soon as they can work out any kinks and find something that will make him balanced instead of gutting him completely.

Balance isn't as easy as you might think. There are a whole lot more statistics to look at that just pick/ban/win rates, and a whole lot more than just statistics to look at. You have to look at team comps, playstyles and everything that is player based and try to balance around that as well, so you don't accidentally get some super strong or super weak team comp in the mix. 

Balance is about keeping that 50% winrate in ALL avenues of play as best as is possible.

Lee Sin has a <50% winrate even in Plat+ with more than 100 Lee games (at least as of a couple weeks ago). Do you feel he should be buffed? Most people feel that Lee Sin is too strong, and yet his winrate defies that. Pick/Ban/Winrates aren't everything in balance, there';s a whole lot more to it.

The statistics I used were Plat V and above, the top 10% of players. 

I am aware of that, but Zed for example has a 50% banrate over all divisions, and a 15% pick rate despite the high ban rate.  He also has a 52% win rate.

Clearly, if he is banned 50% of the time in every division, players are screaming his current state is unhealthy, but they don't even seem to looking in his direction.



Or why when they do nerf something, it seems to be a completely unrelated issue.

Ezreal for example, is recently very popular with the blue build, so they nerf his ultimate.
All his power is on his Q damage/kite potential, so they nerf his ult, leaving the actual problem unresolved.

That's like saying "Annie's burst is too strong, so let's nerf her base AD by 1 per level."

Sarcasm, I assume.

What prompts them to make the change is what I am asking.

They come up with a change, send it to PBE. If no major issue, it would go live. If it is crap, they scrap.

What is their observation that prompts the initial change?
What is the data is used to determine what is "too strong" or "too weak"?

They mainly use win rates, a whole lot of other little things

I assumed they would use win rates, but Alistar is still sub %50, yet he has been nerfed in all the latest patches, AND the one to come.


I don't think I have ever heard someone say, "Damn, that Alistar heal is so game breaking", but I think I would struggle to find someone who doesn't think Zed could do with a little fine tuning.
Most of what they change makes sense but some things are just flat out dumb. The biggest thing they look at would be professional play and perhaps challenjour.
